qas.question: With the intense bomb what did not happen as great as prewar predictions expected?
What witness wrote that these people are staunch to the bone and won't quit?
People called the raids very blitzy like they were talking about what?

context: Although the intensity of the bombing was not as great as prewar expectations so an equal comparison is impossible, no <a0_0>psychiatric crisis<a0_0/> occurred because of the Blitz even during the period of greatest bombing of September 1940. An <a1_0>American<a1_0/> witness wrote "By every test and measure I am able to apply, these people are staunch to the bone and won't quit ... the British are stronger and in a better position than they were at its beginning". People referred to raids as if they were <a2_0>weather<a2_0/>, stating that a day was "very blitzy".:75,261 However, another American who visited Britain, the publisher Ralph Ingersoll, wrote soon after the Blitz eased on 15 September that:
